4 biggest reasons why SEO agencies switch from Semrush to @sitecheckerpro

(we analyzed dozens of closed-won deals)

1/ It became too expensive

- Invited user costs $45 each
- Invited user to the AI visibility toolkit costs $99 each, additionally

The monthly price for a team with 10+ projects often ends with $700-$1k. Sitechecker is x2 cheaper and doesn‚Äôt charge for invited users at all.

2/ It lacks real GSC / GA4 insights

Semrush connects to GSC and GA4, but it doesn‚Äôt think with that data. It doesn‚Äôt have actionable reports that will show you low-hanging fruit.

The real insights are born:

- when you merge GSC and GA4 in one report
- when you combine its data with content changes / new pages tracking
- when you find a unique way to visualise data by pages, segments
- when you give additional options to work with this data, which native GSC / GA4 interfaces don‚Äôt have 

3/ It has non-reliable AI visibility tracking

‚ÄúSemrush has built an AI visibility tool very fast, but at what cost‚Ä¶ The interface and functionality are very basic, and the data is far from accurate.‚Äù (quote from a user on one of the calls)

Yes, it‚Äôs hard to compare the accuracy of AI tracking tools. It‚Äôs not a static Google SERP, and the level of personalization is much higher, but people compare multiple tools for this purpose and have a feeling of what works better.

The problem is that SEMrush does not live up to its status as a market leader, does not keep up with changes, and users worry about what will happen next.

4/ It has too limited support or no support at all

At their help center, you can either book a sales call or have to find the answer yourself. This one hurts the most when you‚Äôre an agency. 

You don‚Äôt have the luxury of ‚Äúwe‚Äôll get back to you‚Äù. You need fast answers, even if the answer is ‚Äúhere‚Äôs a workaround‚Äù.

Have you ever confused by any of these 4 things while using Semrush?

If yes, try Sitechecker for free or ask for a demo in the replies.

Right now, Google's algo is BROKEN! And there are a bunch of ways you can manipulate it without running into many consequences because they switched off or decoupled a lot of the expensive anti-spam systems.

This is the secret freshness recycling SEO technique ‚ôªÔ∏è

It works because Google overweight's recently updated URLs, especially from sites with high craw frequency.

All you have to do is update:
- The Page Date
- Intro paragraph
- Add 1 new section
- Resubmit in GSC
- Repeat every 60-90 days

You don‚Äôt even need new content... You can essentially "bump" old content for free bonus traffic.

I still very much believe that SEO doesn't need to be too complicated.

Back in September, we added a new section to one of our blog posts. This new section came about from checking which queries the content was ranking for and realising we were getting lots of impressions on a certain subject, but the blog post itself didn't meet the needs of that audience.

So we added it!

What happened?

- Clicks per day to the article are up 200%.
- Impressions per day to the article up 834%.
- The page ranked for more queries.

All from taking (probably) 30 minutes in total, from spotting the gap and adding in the content.

It's (still) all about finding what works, and doubling down! :D

‚ÄúBest Pizza‚Äù is a trap.
If you‚Äôre a local business (or a local SEO), trying to rank for national keywords is often a slow, expensive way to lose. The real ROI is in location intent: ‚ÄúBest Pizza M√°laga‚Äù (and thousands of similar queries).

Marketing Feels Expensive When You Cannot See What Is Working

Many law firms invest in marketing every month.
Ads.
SEO.
Content.
Consultants.
Yet clarity is often missing.
Which channel brings the best cases?
Which campaigns actually convert?
Which efforts quietly waste budget?
Without data, marketing feels expensive.
With data, marketing feels controlled.
Real-time tracking changes everything.
Every lead source is visible.
Every conversion is measurable.

AI systems connect marketing activity to real outcomes.
Not just clicks.
Not just impressions.
Actual signed cases.

When firms see the full picture,
they stop guessing.
They stop overcorrecting.
They stop chasing trends.
SEO becomes a long-term asset, not a mystery.
Ads become scalable, not risky.
Marketing becomes a system, not a gamble.
Clarity reduces stress.
Confidence improves decision-making.

The firms that grow fastest
are the ones that know exactly what is driving results.
How clearly can you see what is working in your firm right now?

Small design tweaks can change your website from confusing to captivating. Clear navigation and focused calls to action make your site work harder. Let's chat and make your website shine.

#webdesign #wordpress #websiteaudit #SEO #Rebranding #Buildyourbizonline https://t.co/mfRxrw1FtQ

#2: Improve Navigation üó∫Ô∏è

Confusing navigation = higher bounce rates. 38% of users leave if they can‚Äôt find what they need.

Your hierarchy should be intuitive. Whether it‚Äôs an Organizational Development Platform or a simple landing page, the path to information must be clear. https://t.co/zVdfgfAMIx

Everyone‚Äôs chasing ‚ÄúAI agent infrastructure‚Äù when most SaaS still dies at the landing page
If I don‚Äôt get what your tool does in 2 seconds, I bounce
No amount of vector DBs or autonomous workflows will save you from a confusing homepage
Clear > Clever
Always

Shopify SEO Secrets: Rank #1 in 90 Days (Without Gurus)

Most Shopify stores don‚Äôt fail because SEO is complicated.

They fail because they waste months doing SEO that doesn‚Äôt move revenue an inch.
I‚Äôve seen this play out again and again.

I‚Äôve helped rank over 20 Shopify stores, and the pattern is always the same:

Great products, clean design, but no real SEO strategy.
The problem isn‚Äôt effort.
It‚Äôs focus.

1. From Page Views to Paying Customers

Most Shopify SEO fails at step one.
People target keywords with big numbers because they look impressive.

But ‚Äúwireless headphones‚Äù doesn‚Äôt pay the bills.
‚Äúwireless headphones under $200 for gaming‚Äù does.
]
Here is what works in real life:
-Collection pages target buyer-intent keywords
-Product pages go after highly specific searches
-Blogs support those pages, not the other way around

One store I worked with ignored a 90k/month keyword and focused on a long, ugly phrase no one was excited about.

That single keyword now drives consistent sales every week.

When one of my clients switched from broad terms to buyer-intent phrases, their traffic numbers didn‚Äôt explode overnight‚Ä¶ but their revenue did. Fewer visitors, more orders. That‚Äôs the game.

Ask yourself:
‚ÄúIf someone types this keyword, are they researching, or are they ready to buy?‚Äù

Most stores treat collection pages like a product list.
That quietly kills sales.

2. Your collection pages are quietly killing your revenue

Most brands obsess over product pages and treat collection pages like a boring product list.

That‚Äôs a mistake.
Collection pages are where Google and serious buyers figure out if you‚Äôre the real deal.

What works insanely well:

-Clean URLs: https://t.co/k3WLrekRZO
-Strong titles: Hair Gel for Men ‚Äì Strong Hold & Clean Finish ‚Äì   BrandName
-Short buying guides, comparisons, and FAQs right on the page

One Hair Gel brand I worked with simply added a short ‚ÄúHow to choose your first hair gel‚Äù guide on their collection page.

Result: jumped to page 1, and those pages started printing money.

Your collection pages shouldn‚Äôt just display products.
They should sell the category.

3. Technical SEO isn‚Äôt a PhD subject

A lot of store owners freeze here and think, ‚ÄúThis is too technical.‚Äù

It really isn‚Äôt.
Focus on three basics:

- Simple site structure (no page should be buried 5 clicks deep)
- Fast load times (compress images, remove junk apps)
- A mobile experience that doesn‚Äôt make people pinch and zoom like it‚Äôs 2012

I have seen stores rank better just by removing junk apps, fixing mobile issues, and loading in under 3 seconds.

No tricks.
Just basics done right.
Content that actually sells, not just fills a blog
Random blog posts don‚Äôt build authority.
Strategic content does.

Think in funnels:

-TOFU (Discover): How to build a simple skincare routine for oily skin
-MOFU (Compare): Vitamin C vs niacinamide: which is better for oily skin?
-BOFU (Buy): Best vitamin C serum for oily skin by [Your Brand

Each piece should link deeper into your store:
Blog ‚Üí Collection ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Complementary product.

When we built content like this for a skin care brand, they stopped being ‚Äújust another store‚Äù and became the skin care authority. Guess who Google prefers to rank?

But SEO takes too long‚Ä¶
That‚Äôs the biggest pushback I hear.

Here‚Äôs the truth:
Yes, SEO is not ‚Äúpost today, profit tomorrow.‚Äù

But 90 days is enough to see clear movement if you follow a focused process:

Month 1: Fix structure, on-page, and core technical issues
Month 2: Launch strategic content and internal linking
Month 3: Build a handful of quality backlinks and refine what‚Äôs working

You don‚Äôt wait a year to see movement.

Most stores start seeing real traction within 60‚Äì90 days, not magic rankings, but enough momentum to know it‚Äôs working.

The stores that say ‚ÄúSEO doesn‚Äôt work‚Äù usually quit right before it does.

You don‚Äôt need: ‚ùå Office setup
‚ùå Expensive laptop
‚ùå Coding skills
You need: 
‚úî Problem-solving product
‚úî Etsy SEO basics
‚úî Consistency
That‚Äôs the real requirement.

For more DM
